SEARCH
Package gw.api.rest

Interface IRestDispatchPlugin

All Superinterfaces:
InternalPlugin, Remote
All Known Implementing Classes:
DefaultCloudDispatchPlugin, DefaultRestDispatchPlugin
public interface IRestDispatchPlugin extends InternalPlugin
This class is a plugin whose methods are called during the processing of all requests so customer can control the output and logging. Since these callback occur during the processing of a request, it would be best if they did not throw exceptions, or that new thrown exception could hide an operational or serialization error.

  • Method Details

    • handleReceiveRequest

      void handleReceiveRequest(@NotNull @NotNull RequestContext requestContext)
      This method is called upon receipt of each rest request. The operation handler has not yet been determined (it may be an unsupported path) and the client has not yet been authenticated nor have permissions been checked. The implementer should recognize that the raw content is potentially an attack.

      A customer can implement this method and extract tracking information (see TraceabilityIDConstants.TRACEABILITY_ID_HEADER). if the client has added those headers. Or other information to initialize the MDC. The DefaultRestDispatchPlugin has the methods for manipulating this information, but does *NOT* call the create method in its version of handleReceiveRequest'

      Or a customer can implement logging of the incoming request if they desire.

      Parameters:
      requestContext - the requestContext, this contains information about the request see RequestContext

    • handleReceiveAsyncRequest

      default void handleReceiveAsyncRequest(@NotNull @NotNull jakarta.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest servletRequest)
      This method is called upon receipt of a request that contains the 'Prefer: respond-async' header. It's invoked prior to any other processing such as authentication, authorization, determination of the path is valid possible path in the API, etc.

      Note that the normal handleReceiveRequest(RequestContext) method will still be invoked when the request actually begins processing, unless the request is rejected due to a full queue or a bad 'wait' or 'wait-ms' preference value, so this method does not need to replicate the logic in handleReceiveRequest(RequestContext).

      Parameters:
      servletRequest - the incoming HttpServletRequest

    • handlePreExecute

      void handlePreExecute(@NotNull @NotNull RequestContext requestContext, User user)
      This method is called prior to setting up the execution environment for the known operation and if the operation requires authentication that has been performed.

      At this point the handler has been found: (@link gw.api.pl.rest.RequestContext#getApiFqn()) (@link gw.api.pl.rest.RequestContext#getOperation()) (@link gw.api.pl.rest.RequestContext#getTemplatePath())

      Parameters:
      requestContext - the requestContext, this contains information about the request see RequestContext
      user - the user executing the request, if authentication not required will be null

    • rewriteResponse

      @NotNull @NotNull Response rewriteResponse(@NotNull @NotNull RequestContext requestContext, @NotNull @NotNull Response response)
      This method is called just prior to serializing the response (before writing the response) if the operation handler was called and returned successful.

      A customer can implement this method to modify the response. The default method sets the traceability id into the response if the context has been created.

      Parameters:
      requestContext - the requestContext, this contains information about the request see RequestContext
      response - the response, the response created from the operation handler return value
      Returns:
      a valid response, normally this is just the parameter passed in, but it could create a new response

    • rewriteErrorResponse

      @NotNull @NotNull Response rewriteErrorResponse(@NotNull @NotNull RequestContext requestContext, @NotNull @NotNull Response response)
      This method is called just prior to serializing the response (before writing the response) if the operation handler was called and returned an error. This method is called after the rewriteErrorInfo method, and can be used either in place of rewriteErrorInfo or in conjunction with it, for example to add custom headers to the error response.
      Parameters:
      requestContext - the requestContext, this contains information about the request see RequestContext
      response - the response, the error response created after rewriteErrorInfo has been called
      Returns:
      a valid response, normally this is just the parameter passed in, but it could create a new response

    • rewriteErrorInfo

      @NotNull @NotNull ErrorInfo rewriteErrorInfo(@NotNull @NotNull RequestContext requestContext, @NotNull @NotNull ErrorInfo errorInfo)
      This method permits the customer to change what is revealed in the response for an error. Or if the customer wants to create their own error code hierarchy, they can add the parameter errorInfo as a detail to their newly constructed ErrorInfo. This method is called if there is an error being returned to the client (either during setup, operation execution, or serialization of successful response returned from the operation). The returned ErrorInfo object will be serialized and sent as the response.
      Parameters:
      requestContext - the requestContext, this contains information about the request see RequestContext
      errorInfo - the error that has occurred. Note that this should not be changed (it will be passed to the handleRequestProcessed), but a new errorInfo object can be created.
      Returns:
      the new ErrorInfo object or the passed in errorInfo parameter if unchanged

    • handleRequestProcessed

      void handleRequestProcessed(@NotNull @NotNull RequestContext requestContext, long elapsedMs, Response handlerResponse, ErrorInfo operationError, Response serializedResponse, ErrorInfo serializationError, Throwable writeException)
      This method is called after the request has been processed. The set of parameters to the method will depend upon whether the request succeeded or whether an exception was thrown from during processing, serialization, or writing of the response. In order to make sense of the arguments here, it's helpful to understand the overall control flow:

      . Housekeeping - finding the operation handler, authentication, permission checking, etc -- which may populate an operationError argument (handlerResponse, serializationResponse, and serializationError arguments will be null). . Otherwise, the operation handler is invoked. It returns handlerResponse argument if successful. If an exception is thrown, the error info is stored in the operationError argument (handlerResponse, serializationResponse, and serializationError arguments will be null). . If the operation handler was successfully, the serializedResponse argument is constructed by serializing that result. If an exception is thrown, the errorInfo is stored in the serializationError argument (serializationResponse will be null). . Lastly, either the serializedResponse (if it was created) or a serialized errorInfo will be written to the output stream. If that write throws an exception, the writeException argument will be non-null

      Looking at the state of the arguments thus allows you to reconstruct whether the request was successfully processed, if it failed due to a client error (i.e. bad input, a resource that doesn't exist, etc.) or due to a server error (i.e. a bug in the handler, the handler returning invalid output that couldn't be serialized, etc.), and whether the failure occurred during request processing or during the attempt to serialize and write the response out.

      In the default implementation we do the logging only in this method and this method will close the traceability context, if it was created.

      Parameters:
      requestContext - the requestContext see RequestContext
      elapsedMs - the milli secs it as taken to execute any other the above methods and the api itself
      handlerResponse - the response from the api handler
      operationError - any errorInfo from finding and executing the operation handler
      serializedResponse - if there was a handlerResponse, this is the serialized content
      serializationError - any errorInfo from the serialization
      writeException - any exception from the write (typically IOException)

    • handleAsyncResponse

      default void handleAsyncResponse(@NotNull @NotNull jakarta.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest servletRequest, int responseCode, boolean failedBeforeProcessing)
      This method is called when the response is sent to a request that contains the 'Prefer: respond-async' header. It's invoked after closing the response to the request. There are four different ways in which an async request can end:
      • The request is accepted for async processing, and a 202 response code is returned
      • The request is rejected if all executor threads are in use and the async queue is full, and a 503 response code is returned
      • The 'Prefer' header has an errant 'wait' or 'wait-ms' preference value, and 400 response code is returned
      • The request completes synchronously. This can happen either because no 'wait' or 'wait-ms' preference is specified and the request errors out prior to the API handler beginning, or because the 'wait' or 'wait-ms' preference was specified and the request completed prior to the specified time. In this case, the responseCode will match whatever the request completed with.

      Note that the normal handleReceiveRequest and handleRequestProcessed methods will still be invoked when the request actually begins processing, unless the request is rejected due to a full queue or a bad 'wait' or 'wait-ms' preference value, so this method does not need to replicate the logic in those methods.

      Parameters:
      servletRequest - the incoming HttpServletRequest
      responseCode - the response code that was sent back to the caller.
      failedBeforeProcessing - true if the request failed before going through normal request processing, such that the normal handleReceiveRequest and handleRequestProcessed methods will not be invoked, and false if the request was either accepted for processing or completed synchronously
